g.text: 1.5 ppm is in very good agreement
with the chemical shift value reported previously for LiOH.
The relative intensities of the two signals at
as shown in Figure 7a, are very close to the 1:1 ratio.
Considering these observations we propose the following
protonation mechanism: After a water molecule is adsorbed at
the surface of the material it follows the reaction H
ions are incorporated in the garnet and Li
excluded from it in order to maintain the charge balance. These
ions react with the remaining OH
the overall ratio of both proton populations very close to 1:1.
In order to further characterize the reaction of the garnet
with atmospheric humidity, the eﬀects on the Li local
Li spectra of the garnet sample before
signals are apparently similar, there is a clear broadening of the
Li spectrum after exposure, as shown in the overlay of the
ﬁgure. Unfortunately an accurate line-shape analysis of the
individual contributions to this signal is diﬃcult due to strong
when comparing the saturation recovery experiments shown in
Figure 7c. The magnetization recovery data of LZLGO
(represented by squares in the ﬁgure) were ﬁtted using a
single exponential function, and a T
obtained. For H-LZLGO, on the other hand, the build-up curve
could only be correctly ﬁtted using a multiple exponential
function. The results of the ﬁttings are shown in Figure 7, and
the ﬁtting parameters are found in Table 4. All
components obtained for H-LZLGO are diﬀerent from the
original value obtained for LZLGO, indicating that the
protonation process of the garnet has clear eﬀects on the
population of the garnet. This can only be explained
by the presence of structural changes in the garnet induced by
material. We can thus expect very clear eﬀects in the Li-ion
conductivity upon protonation. Similar eﬀects have also been
H NMR signal at 4.8 ppm to
protons inside the garnet. In principle, LiOH being formed
inside the structure of the garnet or at the surface of the
particles are both in agreement with the NMR data discussed so
far. Nevertheless, structural steric obstruction and the data
obtained previously by neutron diﬀraction data on partially
protonated garnets, where the LiOH was not observed in the
show that LiOH can hardly be ascribed as structural.
By examination of the diﬀerent Li
Table 4 we see that the minor
with a population of 0.1 is in fact very long and is in agreement
values previously reported for bulk LiOH.
compounds cannot be directly compared with the values
reported in Table 4 since the phases formed here are probably
amorphous and interacting with the surface of the material.
This will have an impact in the relaxation of lithium, and an
unambiguous assignment cannot be based on a direct
comparison of the values. The impact of the degree of
crystallinity of a phase in its mobility and hence in the
longitudinal relaxation values was described previously.

sample. The former was interpreted as low-mobility Li (
